You mention the value offered by the humanities. The one you didn't mention is wisdom.

We've been great at building a technocratic society, and we all enjoy the benefits. But without the humanities, how is one supposed to put in context and assess wisely what one should do with the technological capabilities developed?

You also didn't mention the problem of the modern research university which emphasizes discrete disciplines rather than a humanistic whole.

Even the discipline of philosophy itself has become just that -- one discipline among others -- and has given up the task of offering wisdom.

The philosopher Alfred North Whitehead said something once about a civilization being in full decay without a sense of adventure. Adventure is something we only can understand by way of a humanistic context.

Without a strong, lived sense of the humanities, we may have economic growth and productivity, but I doubt that we'll experience anything like an intense sense of adventure -- because adventure is not just a matter of striking out in one direction or another but of somehow moving forward, and forward is a notion that has to be grounded one way or another in the wisdom of the humanities.

Carbona, The hegemony of American art has a lot to do with military and economic might

Carbona,

I don't see any relevance in comparing "artistic output" among disparate nations. It is entirely possible that as large and wealthy a country as the U.S. can discourage 98 or 99 percent of the talent it produces and, if absolute numbers of persons engaged in artistic endeavors remain large enough, such might still outproduce in sheer volume countries with smaller numbers of working artists.

Also, I was not writing specifically about popular entertainers, who can range from complete unknowns to one-hit wonders to fabulous and seemingly lifelong material successes. (As examples of the latter think Eric Clapton, Bob Dylan, Paul McCartney, the Rolling Stones, Paul Simon, etc.)

Rather, I was referring to people who study an artistic specialty complex enough to require serious institutional preparation as, at minimum, part of a four-year degree program and who, after substantial investments of time and money, might reasonably expect to establish careers wherein they can earn a sustaining income by creating, composing, and/or performing their art until a reasonable retirement age, vis-a-vis that of the general population.

It wouldn't surprise if ratios of successful to unsuccessful popular entertainers mirror those of more classically trained and oriented artists. I suspect that the pain of 'failure' might be proportional to energy, time, and money expended in preparation, but lack sufficient data for comparing such experiences among classical vs. popular artists.

"The situation is even worse for those who want to produce the literary, musical and artistic works that sustain our humanistic culture...."

Prof. Gutting, I can't recall ever having seen this problem summarized as concisely as you have managed in your eighth paragraph. It seems almost criminal that, often after incurring substantial debt in pursuit of their degrees, students in the arts can be left at the mercy of "market discipline."

I doubt it 's much of an exaggeration to suggest that one or two percent of actors, musicians, and fine artists earn about 98 or 99 percent of the money available to practitioners of their various specialties.

Even worse, sometimes it seems that we in the U.S. discourage -- Read "starve out of existence" -- more of these forms of talent in one year than traditional artistic centers of Europe, i.e., France, Germany, or Italy, produce in a century. As you rightly point out, the problem isn't that those who 'fail' are insufficiently talented to succeed, but simply unable to attain sufficient stature in their specialties quickly enough to achieve self-supporting status.

Those fortunate enough to establish alternative careers can be reluctant to jeopardize reliable livelihoods for the meager opportunities available to "part-timers."

The net result, artistically and economically, is a deplorable waste of talent and treasure. But, still, the institutions cash the tuition checks, while even working artists fare little better than "The Help."

I don't think unvaccinated kids should be allowed to attend public school.
Let them go to a school with other kids of like minded parents, who take science into their own hands. My mother told me that her family lived in fear of developing polio.
I had measles, german measles, mumps and chicken pox in my childhood, all miserable diseases only made better by my mother's devotion to my bedside, stroking my head as I moaned and reading Little Women and Heide to me for the many quieter hours of terrible boredom and discomfort waiting for the viruses to leave my body.
As a physician today,I am hounded by every hospital I am on staff at to prove I had my flu vaccine ( I did, and in early October) as you are not allowed to stay on a hospital staff without all vaccines up to date and a negative annual TB test, because it would be irresponsible to potentially expose patients to a healer who is sick themselves.
If you don't vaccinate your children, you are basically taking a stance that that is similar to not allowing your child to ever ride in a car for fear of an accident. it is far mor likely statistically for a child to be injured or die from a car accident than from a side effect from a vaccine.

Dr. K,

You have a huge responsibility as a teacher of economics and an equally serious responsibility in your public role as a columnist for this newspaper. I very much appreciate how you discharge that responsibility. Your stewardship is amazing and we all profit from it.

I totally agree with your comment: "Economic history — global economic history — should be a core part of the curriculum." for all disciplines. The economic behavior of our species is fundamental to our understanding of the world and ourselves.

Our expression of basic instincts: to eat, avoid being eaten, and to reproduce as it is translated through our herd instinct seems to drive our society. For example, we can easily adapt to a stressed environment by adapting the behavior of lemmings. That is why we must be watchful over the adaptation of free market capitalism because we can easily be influenced by leadership to do ourselves in as we stampede into the future.

As a social and economic system we have not been doing well. This last contraction should not have happened and we should be vigilent to prevent a occurrence. We are at a critical point in the US on the issue of deficit spending, social insurance, fair taxation, and the role of government in supporting innovation.

Many of your readers, including me, do not accept the notion that secular stagnation is here to stay. It is unacceptable, so let's fix it. Experiment, do anything to restore jobs, livable wages and household formations.

We're up early to get him to his bus. He's making good money but he's a cheap so-and-so, so he takes the Vietnamese bus from LA to San Jose. $40 and, as you get on, they hand you a Vietnamese sandwich, a bottle of water and a coupon for having your nails done. In lieu of an airport, they use the parking lot of Lee's Sandwiches, in south San Jose. It's a schlep but not too bad on Sunday morning. Picking him up during rush hour on Wednesday was no fun.

They play Vietnamese karaoke for five hours and the whole bus sings with gusto. He's getting to know many of the tunes. They have some strange rituals, like the bus driver not talking to anyone when he pulls into the parking lot until he has smoked a cigarette. Alex knows this is disconcerting for the first-time passengers so acts as a kind of tour guide to nervous newbies.

On Wednesday he had to run a business meeting during the trip, so they agreed to suspend the singing for 1/2 hour while he conducted business on his cell. That's my boy.
Prn is as needed, not pen. And drug name confusion is rampant for both doctors and nurses. I always confirm online

Interesting topic for providers and patients alike.
A) For those concerned with the fact that a Nurse was "ordering" a medication for her patient, it is likely that this patient already had and order (prescription) for the medication on a pen (as needed) basis from their attending physician but that it had not yet been delivered to that unit from Pharmacy, especially if this was the first incident in which this patient needed the drug. Granted, these medications are usually kept in a floor stock, but, these things do happen.
B) There are countless electronic record/medication administration software systems in use depending one which facility you're practicing at. Many offer a change in settings to work primarily with the generic or trade name, which the other being listed second.
C) It would be favorable for more nurses (and physicians alike) to retain information (such as medication's generic and trade name) for longer than just the time required for examinations in school but throughout one's practice. Granted, resources exist so that immediate recall of this information isn't "crucial" on the floor, but health care professionals are one group of people that I always would like to see over-prepared for a situation.

This issue is similar to the effort to eliminate various systems of measures in documentation/orders. Institutions have standards in place to help mitigate this problem, but unauthorized labels still show up on occasioned must then be corrected.

I have read the Apostolic Exhortation and believe that Pope Francis has compellingly challenged global capitalism as it has been practiced for the past 35 or so years.

The Pope calls for an end of trickle-down economics and the economics of exclusion. That suggests that inequalities should be reduced within nations as well as between nations. The Pope's emphasis on localism also suggests that wealth should be dispersed across broader geographies than is now the case, rather than concentrated key capital centers. The Pope further calls for the rich to use their wealth to benefit the poor, which can be interpreted as support for socially responsible investment. These are important messages.

The Pope asks that economic change be undertaken through the political realm. This suggests that the Pope supports governmental actions that reduce the gap between rich and poor, enhance the opportunities available to the least affluent and ensure that sufficient resources are available to all. The Apostolic Exhortation is thus a direct challenge to laissez-faire capitalism and public policies that support it-- the dominant influences on governance over the past several decades.

I agree with Francis that new or modified economic and governmental paradigms are needed to blunt the sharp edge of market capitalism. These paradigms have been emerging, and include socially responsible and investments that bolster community-based economies that help the poor.

Nature is pretty awesome in Alaska. I once caught a 180-pound halibut in Prince William Sound. I hauled the "barn door" up in about 250' of water, and the captain told me the spot we were fishing was dry land before the 1964 magnitude 9.2 earthquake. That really makes you think.

There's a park in Anchorage dedicated to the quake, with a photo of the area in front of you from before '64. The cliffs that are there now and weren't then are not to be believed. A story from a past governor tells about how he was about to be crushed by a runaway house when a hole opened up in the earth and swallowed the house, saving him.

"Active volcano" in Alaska is something that could theoretically sterilize a thousand square miles without a moment's notice. It's quite a place.

What you write is really worth paying attention to.    With the emphasis more and more being on teaching skills versus critical thinking and free thinking, I sense that in the decades ahead I will live in a world where people are not free to contemplate the world around them, their place in it, moral obligations, consequences of decisions made.  Instead  every human being will be 'trained' to think of himself as a widget on constant treadmill working for wages and nothing more with no care for other people and no sense of ethics.  Thinking about this kind of future is nothing less than frightening.

In the country where I am living, there is little emphasis on the teaching of humanities. University education has been, by and large emphasizing about technical skills. The consequence is that we have generations of youth lacking the desire to quest new insights of everything from poetry and paintings to business models and politics. They lost the very basic ability to learn how to think creatively and critically, to reason, and to ask questions about things happened in their lives.

Over years of my tenure in my present company, I've observed many young engineers lack the conscious to develop ability to gain insights of things occurred in their daily life, the need to understand the world and to bring clarity to the future. Their minds are regressive when confronting about ethical questions. Some even reject ideas to promote learning another language which might help them to gain an appreciation for the similarities in different cultures.

That's probably explained why so many can hardly move up in the value chain of job market. On the other hand, jobs which are intellectually demanding and require intensive innovation are scant.

In the context of where I live, the crisis of humanities is even deeper. To reverse the general perception on the nature and value of humanistic knowledge, it is going to be long long way and I am sure it is going to be costly too. I hope other part of the world would not slip into the similar dilemma.

THE Republican supreme court said drug co's are free to advertise, another reason for overuse of expensive look alines and another reason why doctors have to waste time explaining to a patient who believes the ads.

Len, you just hit the nail on the head. Why in the world are prescription-only drugs advertised on TV at all? You can't just go out to the store and buy them. Prescription drugs are powerful, potentially dangerous drugs that can be beneficial only if used in the proper way and at the proper dose, and their use should be determined only by your physician, using his medical knowledge and experience.
I also remember a time when advertising prescription-only drugs to the public was not only unethical, but illegal. But deregulation, and lobbying by Big Pharma now allows this ridiculous practice, presumably so that people will now go and pester their doctors for drugs they may not need and which may even endanger their lives, just so that Big Pharma can make more profits. Corporate greed is ruining this country.

LHan - I do not believe prescription drug advertising is the result of a SCOTUS decision. It is regulated by the FCA which could put conditions on it to make it impossible. Or Congress could direst the FDA to make do so.

Practitioners tend to use trade names for drugs they prescribe. Perhaps it's because they are overwhelmed by advertising and the promos from detail men and women. Or, perhaps, they are simply responding in a language most patients understand, trade, not generic or chemical names. Most likely it is some of both.

Perhaps the solution to this mid-level drug problem (wrong meds dispensed and drug interactions are the much bigger problems) is for the F.D.A. to require that every advertisement for a proprietary med mention the generic name each time they mention the trade name. That will help on the demand side, helping attune patients to the generic. On the supply side, practitioners should should be trained in school and continually encouraged to use the generic, even while understanding they have to be ready to use trade names when needed for the patient to understand.

Insurance companies probably could help by highlighting generic names in their formularies .

However, while this molehill may need attending, it is not the mountains of mis-dispensed drugs (and the usual inability of a patient to find an in-house system willing to deal with such) and dangerous drug interactions resulting from the fragmented medical care available to most Americans.

In 2012 there were exactly six athletic departments at "BCS" universities that took no subsidies from their university budgets--LSU, Nebraska, Ohio State, Oklahoma, Penn State, Purdue and Texas. Five historically powerful and lucrative athletic football programs, and one that strives for an 85% on-time "student-athlete" graduation rate:
http://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/college/2013/05/07/ncaa-finances-su...

The relatively small amounts of funding required for reputable arts and humanities programs at universities ought to make more emphasis a no-brainer. However, the article accurately points out the problem--what will graduates with those degrees do to pursue careers? Admirably educated, some find other careers where writing, thinking critically, and understanding others are assets; others cannot pull that off. The overriding emphasis on training for jobs does not encourage university managements in that direction. About the most universities can do is require substantive general education requirements to prevent graduates from being total "STEM Philistines."

Most of the fiction authors whose outputs I have totally read over the decades have university appointments to pay the bills while pursuing what they presumably would prefer to do full-time. They still get their novels out, but lesser lights are unlikely to come home after a long day in the HR department and break out the oils, the unfinished piano piece, or the nascent short story.

I am typically of the opinion that sport is overhyped and overfunded.

However when you ask "why do universities subsidise sports?" And say there is no reason to do so I must disagree. Sports like football and basketball are as much an art form as any other performance art.

Sports(wo)men and the sports they perform for us merely evoke different emotions in their audiences than what is typically referred to by "arts and humanities". Emotions of triumph, suspense, empathy of struggle and so forth. Judging from the passion of followers it is a very successful art form in this regard.

It is a very real and upsetting elitism that the educated and intelligent look down their nose at popular sports and fail to recognise their artistic value even if it doesn't appeal to them personally.

The traditional arts and humanities definitely deserve a bigger share of the support than they have, but in an ideal world sports would share in that support as well. Although the more popular forms of art and sport are always going to have more money from patronage.

I believe strongly that sports provides an important part of a college education. I find that my students who do athletics have a much higher sense of self discipline than my other students. They respond well to academic "coaching", and when several members of a team work together on group problem solving in class, they do extremely well. I was surprised by this, as I have no interest in sports myself, and subconsciously bought into the stereotype of the 'dumb jock" before experience taught me otherwise.

However, my school has the second LOWEST funding for athletics of any other school in the CSU system. We have no football team, no basketball team. My students play golf, volley ball, tennis, water polo, and all sorts of other sports that get little attention from the media. Consequently, they play only for the love of the sport, and don't train heavily enough to detract from their studies. They are better students because of it.

Mr. Gutting, you hit the head on the nail with this comment: "Even major universities subsidize professional sports through their (mostly money-losing) athletic programs, which provide a continuing influx of professional players. Universities could reduce their efforts to field teams playing at near-professional levels and direct the money saved to artistic activities much closer to their core mission."

Why do universities subsidize sports? I don't see any academic reason for their support of football and basketball particularly. All the hype that goes into college rivalries seems to me a pathetic waste of emotion and resources. A college is an educational institution. When the football coach is paid more than the university president, what are we teaching?

I think this is unfair. I did my medical training and residency recently, so recently that I had virtually no exposure to pharmaceutical reps in medical school, residency, or fellowship. Therefore, my choice in generic versus brand names is not from "excessive in-clinic marketing." The brand name is often shorter, quicker to write on prescriptions, and easier to convey to families in a way that is understandable. However, I know both the brand and generic names for the medications I use - although it would be nice not to have to use the brain capacity to retain both.

In my opinion, if people have a problem with the usage of multiple names for the same drug, criticizing doctors (while a common response to any type of problem) may not be as appropriate as expressing the concerns to the appropriate regulatory agencies.

Max, Demerol is NOT a commonly-prescribed drug. It has fallen out of favor, mainly because it has a metabolite that can build up and be harmful, especially to older patients. There are better, safer opioid medications that can be used. It may still have some uses in certain circumstances, such as the rigors Ms. Brown described. And Mrs. Smith may prefer Zoloft to sertraline, but I'll bet you her insurance company only pays for the generic sertraline.

Sorry to say this Paul, but in certain circles you have become a fuddy-duddy defender of the status quo.

Consider your defense of the economics profession. I know that there are highly competent honest economists, but, by and large, they aren't the ones we see being quoted in the newspapers and appearing on TV. Worse, they aren't the ones being published in the most prestigious economics journals. Any profession that hasn't drummed Rogoff and Reinhardt out of it after their recent fiasco and disingenuous defence isn't worthy of the name.

Congratulations to you and Summers for your new secular stagnation theory, but others have been warning for decades of the danger to demand that excessive inequality posed, something which you ignore.

Many of us find the argument that excessive inequality hinders growth compelling. For example, there is the reduction in demand just mentioned (billionaires don't spend their income as the rest of us do). Also great inequality inevitably leads to great inequality of opportunity so that the most talented are not filling the most important positions. In fact, we find the argument so compelling that we are willing to accept it unless it is contradicted by empirical evidence. For you, it is the opposite: you won't accept the argument until there is compelling empirical evidence for it.
